articles.title: NPDC Seek Public Input Into Plan To Manage Impacts Of Climate Change
articles.author: Scoop
articles.summary: NPDC Climate Change Response Lead Greg Stephens says a changing climate can provide opportunities to act and build a future where people can thrive in a changing environment. Greg Stephens is the leader of the NPDC's climate change response team. He is also a member of the UNFCCC.

articles.title: From Antarctica to Connecticut: the climate connection
articles.author: Steve Glazier
articles.summary: Chase Cain traveled to Antarctica to document the impacts of climate change on the frozen continent. The water off Antarctica has warmed nearly two degrees since 1955 and is warming three times as fast as the global average. More than 100 billion tons of ice melt from Antarctica each year and sea levels are rising twice as fast than 25 years ago.

articles.title: Major hurricane conference kicks off in New Orleans. Federal experts were missing.
articles.author: Kasey Bubnash
articles.summary: The National Hurricane Conference kicked off in New Orleans on Monday, but there were no federal officials from NOAA and FEMA. Travel restrictions placed on federal employees by the Trump administration are to blame for the lack of representation. Since Trump took office, NOAA has faced repeated threats of staffing and funding cuts. Last week, the administration proposed eliminating the agency's research arm.

articles.title: Insane 'Mother Jones' Goes Full Crazy Leftist and Calls for a Ban On ... Dogs
articles.author: justmindy
articles.summary: Mother Jones is calling for a ban on dogs. New research shows that dogs have 'extensive and multifarious' environmental impacts, disturbing wildlife, polluting waterways and contributing to carbon emissions. The internet is full of memes about the topic.   Twitter is in full support of the ban.

articles.title: Pollen alert: Climate change extends allergy season worldwide
articles.author: AMM
articles.summary: Climate change is causing an increase in pollen levels, leading to a rise in seasonal allergies. Scientists predict that pollen levels will exceed the historical average in 39 U.S. states this season. People suffering from allergies may experience symptoms for a longer period. This is partly due to rising levels of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere.

articles.title: Prince George area Snowpack sees improvement in April bulletin
articles.author: Darin Bain
articles.summary: It was a wet March in the Prince George area. The snowpack in the Upper Fraser West basin increased to 94% of normal on April 1st. The Upper Fraser East saw an improvement up to 79%. The provincial average for snowpack was at 79%, an improvement from 73%.

articles.title: NPDC Seek Public Input Into Plan To Manage Impacts Of Climate Change
articles.author: New Zealand Go...
articles.summary: By 2050 New Plymouth could have almost 17 extra days above 25 degrees each year. The hottest day each year could be 2 degrees hotter. The 10-year plan for 2024-34 includes a budget for climate change planning of $490,000 in year one and $640,000 per annum in year two onwards. NPDC agreed to continue the Planting Our Place program and boost a high-frequency bus trial budget.

articles.title: Global Greening Reaches New High From CO2 Fertilisation
articles.author: Principia Scientific
articles.summary: Climate 'refugees' don't exist, and climate 'tipping points' exist only in computer models, so there are no such things as climate refugees or tipping points in the climate system. There is no such thing as a "tipping point" for climate change.

articles.title: Some unlucky ducks: Ducks and other waterbird populations are on the decline
articles.author: Erin Holly
articles.summary: Bird experts report that some water bird species in the Coastal Bend are experiencing population declines as their nesting habitats are disappearing. The number of shorebirds in North America has decreased by 33% since 1980. People can help preserve bird populations by giving them space to nest undisturbed and by picking up trash.

articles.title: Weather pattern shifting in the Big Country, here's what it could mean
articles.author: Katalina Bell
articles.summary: As we head into the warmer months, we could be in store for some changes in our weather patterns. There are two main phases of the El Niño-Southern Oscillation: El Niño and La Niña. There's also a third phase called ENSO Neutral, when ocean temperatures and wind patterns are more or less where they 'should' be for this time of year. ENSo Neutral is expected to stick around through the summer. The big thing to watch will be whether we start to see a steady inflow of Gulf moisture.

articles.title: Sophisticated pyrotechnology in the Ice Age: This is how humans made fire tens of thousands ...
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: Fire was essential for the survival of people in the Ice Age, but there are hardly any well-preserved examples of its use.    It is assumed that fire was used for cooking, heating, as a light source, or for making tools.

articles.title: Aussie mum's scary insurance dilemma after double disaster: 'Nowhere is untouched'
articles.author: Michael Dahlstrom
articles.summary: Chay Khamsone lives in Pappinbarra on the NSW Mid-North Coast, which has been hit by bushfires in 2019 and floods in 2021. More than 2 million properties are now difficult to insure because of climate change. 86 suburbs are classified as 'critical climate risk zones', where 80 to 100% of the properties are at high risk.

articles.title: Beyond the Forecast: The impact climate change has had on South Florida's rain season
articles.author: Steve MacLaughlin
articles.summary: Climate change has made South Florida's rainy, heat and hurricane seasons much more dangerous. In 2023, several 6' rain events plus a lot of smaller events added up to a record-shattering 113.61' in Fort Lauderdale. Since 1970, Miami has seen a 12% increase in rainfall intensity and 88% of cities have seen an average of 15% rainfall intensity increase since 1970.

articles.title: ABC News Blames Tornado Surge On Climate Change—But Data Says Otherwise
articles.author: Stu Turley
articles.summary: There was a record number of tornadoes in March in the U.S. and over 200 tornadoes were recorded. According to ABC News, the recent tornado outbreak was caused by climate change. NCEI, the National Centers for Environmental Information, disagrees with ABC's claims and says the data is not reliable.

articles.title: Rising temperatures may cause mental health disorders: Study
articles.author: News Room
articles.summary: Rising temperatures due to climate change could increase the burden of mental disorders in Australia by 50% by 2050. High temperatures led to an annual loss of 8,459 disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) between 2003 and 2018, according to the report.

articles.title: IIT Bombay Reveals Why South Asian Heat Waves Escalate
articles.author: IANS
articles.summary: Researchers at the Indian Institute of Technology Bombay have found different climatic drivers behind back-to-back extreme heat events experienced by South Asian countries including India, Pakistan, and Afghanistan. The research reveals a concerning pattern: one heatwave can set the stage for another, more intense heat event in the following weeks.

articles.title: Rovers reserves ‘on fire'
articles.author: Contributed
articles.summary: The Deni Rovers reserves played against Blighty on Saturday. The day was hot because of a later start and the sun was at its hottest. The game was played in front of a crowd of 1,000 people at the Craven Cottage Stadium.

articles.title: Terminations at US government agencies that monitor extreme weather events will have negative effects
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: In August 2021, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change Report confirmed that the climate is warming and the impacts will be more intense than anticipated. In 2023, the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) reports on "The Dangerous Trump Purge of Weather and Climate Expertise".

articles.title: When ice ages end, ocean circulation fine-tunes ocean heat
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Much of Earth's heat uptake is passed to the ocean. Ocean heat content is typically lower during ice ages and rises during warmer periods of glacier retreat, which is key for understanding long-term climate patterns. Over time, ocean heat content rises with glacier retreat.

articles.title: Climate crisis has tripled length of deadly ocean heatwaves, study finds
articles.author: Damian Carrington
articles.summary: Half of the marine heatwaves since 2000 would not have happened without global heating caused by burning fossil fuels. The heatwaves have become more frequent and more intense. The Mediterranean Sea is 5C hotter than in the 1940s. More than 90% of the extra heat trapped by greenhouse gas emissions is stored in the ocean.

articles.title: CAF study says collective planning needed concerning regional water scarcity
articles.author: Malaika
articles.summary: A study by CAF – Development Bank of Latin America and the Caribbean has shed light on the water security challenges confronting Dominica and the Eastern Caribbean. CAF convened a High-Level Technical Workshop on Water and Sanitation in the Caribbean in Bridgetown, Barbados, on April 8-9, 2025. It aimed to discuss the study's findings and explore actionable solutions for the pressing water security issues affecting the region.

articles.title: Long-term decline signals in Australia's coal exports
articles.author: Steel Radar
articles.summary: Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis (IEEFA) says Australia may be facing a long-term decline in both metallurgical and thermal coal exports. Official national projections indicate that global energy transition is taking place. IEEFA's research is based on national projections.

articles.title: Climate change set to deepen Australia's mental health crisis by 2050: study
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Rising temperatures could increase the burden of mental and behavioral disorders (MBDs) in Australia by nearly 50 percent by 2050. Extreme heat contributes to the annual loss of 8,458 disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) making up 1.8 percent of the country's total MBD burden. Young Australians aged 15 to 44 are particularly affected by it.

articles.title: Poof! There Goes America's Competitive Advantage in a Warming World
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: The Trump administration's governance and the president's unhinged trade war hurt America's ability to meet climate goals, writes Julian Zelizer. He points to President Trump's "unhinged" trade war on the entire world as the reason.    for this.

articles.title: Coalition scores just 1/100 points for environment and climate policies from conservation organisation
articles.author: The Observer
articles.summary: The Coalition has been awarded 1 out of 100 for its environment and climate change policies. It's the lowest score the conservation organisation has given the Liberal and National parties in more than 20 years. The Coalition has failed every single test, according to the organisation.

articles.title: Three of Australia's riskiest areas for property insurance are in the Hunter
articles.summary: There are 38,995 properties considered "high risk" in federal electorates of Robertson, Dobell and Hunter. The biggest risks in these areas are bushfires, riverine flooding, extreme wind and surface flooding. Dobell is the ninth riskiest federal electorate nationwide for property insurance becoming inaccessible.

articles.title: Ice Age Fire Masters: How Ancient Humans Maintained Advanced Flames During Earth's Coldest Period
articles.author: Studyfinds Staff
articles.summary: Stone Age humans used spruce as a primary fuel during the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) 23,000 years ago. Their hearths reached temperatures up to 600°C and they used it for cooking, tool production, and keeping warm in subzero temperatures. The discovery challenges previous assumptions that humans retreated to southern refuges during extreme cold periods.

articles.title: 40+ Groups: Trump Admin Push to Dismantle FEMA a 'Direct Threat' to Millions
articles.author: Jessica Corbett
articles.summary: Trump administration wants to dismantle the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). The coalition of over 40 organizations rejects the idea and calls on Congress to defend FEMA. The coalition's letter is in response to Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem's declaration last month that "we're going to eliminate FEMA."

articles.title: Spring drought threatens Europe's farms and rivers
articles.summary: There is a drought in Central and Eastern Europe due to a lack of rainfall and unseasonably warm weather. The present conditions resemble those ahead of Europe's devastating 2018 drought. If it doesn't rain in the coming weeks, there could be serious impacts on agriculture.

articles.title: How insurance could reshape conservation economics in Africa
articles.summary: The Africa Insurance Risk Pool for Nature was launched to prevent human-wildlife conflict in Africa. The demographic boom has seen Africa's population nearly triple in the past four decades. There is a massive expansion in agricultural and residential settlements into previously wild landscapes. Climate change is exacerbating these conflicts through prolonged droughts and shifting wildlife movements.

articles.title: Treat heatwaves as a health emergency
articles.author: Aparna Roy
articles.summary: The health consequences of heatwaves are widespread, affecting both urban and rural populations. The most vulnerable are outdoor workers, the rural poor, pregnant women, and the elderly. The introduction of heat action plans across approximately 23 states and Union Territories was a step in the right direction, but fragmented implementation limits their effectiveness. The National Action Plan on Heat-Related Illness has yet to be updated with a clear roadmap for mainstreaming climate-health integration into India's broader public health system.

articles.title: Grass fire tears through acre of Barrie land
articles.author: Julianna Balsamo
articles.summary: A large grass fire raged across an acre of land in Barrie, Ont. on April 13, 2025. Locals saw flames and heavy smoke and were worried about the safety of the area.    Lonnie Murphy, Lonnie Murphy's son.

articles.title: New Study Finds The Anthropogenic ‘Pressure' On Climate Is Too Small To Play A ‘Dominant Role'
articles.author: Kenneth Richard
articles.summary: Geology professor Dr. Wojciech Stankowski explains why humans can't drive climate change by burning more or less fossil fuels. Past natural climate changes such as Greenland's temperature increases of up to 10°C within 50 years 14,700 and 11,700 years ago confirm that the modern climate change rate is within the range of natural variability.

articles.title: Oman launches national campaign on weather, tsunami risks
articles.author: Joydeep B
articles.summary: Oman's National Committee for Emergency Management (NCEM) launched a four-day national awareness campaign on the risks associated with weather phenomena, climate change, and tsunamis in Sur, South Sharqiyah on Monday. The initiative aims to raise public awareness about natural disaster preparedness.

articles.title: Rep. Maria Cervania on western NC recovery, retaining top talent, and bills she's working to advance
articles.author: Clayton Henkel
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene devastated western North Carolina more than six months ago. Legislators are concerned about the impact of the Trump administration's budget and staffing cuts to federal agencies and price hikes caused by new Trump tariffs. NC Newsline caught up with state Rep. Maria Cervania from her Legislative Building office to discuss her concerns for western N.C.

articles.title: Policy reversals threaten progress NZ has made on reducing emissions
articles.author: Andrea Graves
articles.summary: Carbon dioxide levels continue to rise. Measurement stations at Baring Head off the Wainuiomata coast and in Hawai'i measure higher levels of the gas. The smell around the Beehive seems to be of decay, not carbon dioxide.

articles.title: Scientists Claim Climate Change Is Causing People to Commit Suicide
articles.author: Ellie Gardey Holmes
articles.summary: A group of European and Canadian scientists wrote an article in Nature Medicine about the link between climate change and suicide. They assert that 7 percent of suicides will be caused by warming temperatures by 2035. They also postulate that climate change will cause mental disorders, which will result in a greater number of suicides.

articles.title: BMKG Reports Warming Sea Surface Temperature as Dry Season Approaches Indonesia
articles.author: Zacharias Wuragil
articles.summary: The sea surface temperature in the Indonesian region is warmer than normal. This influence is through the increased formation of rain clouds. The anomaly is projected to persist until September. Erma Yulihastin, a climate research professor at the Climate and Atmosphere Research Center of the National Research and Innovation Agency (BRIN), confirms that all sea surface temperatures are warming.

articles.title: Proposed Trump budget cuts target NOAA climate research agencies that Texas relies on
articles.author: Justin Ballard
articles.summary: The Trump administration is preparing to dismantle core climate research functions of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The proposed budget cuts NOAA funding from $6.1 billion in 2025 to $4.5 billion in the next budget, a savings of less than $5 per person in the United States.

articles.title: IIT Bombay Study Shows Why South Asia Repeatedly Faces Extreme Heat Waves
articles.author: Indo-Asian News Service
articles.summary: Researchers at the Indian Institute of Technology Bombay have found different climatic drivers behind back-to-back extreme heat events experienced by South Asian countries including India, Pakistan, and Afghanistan. The research reveals a concerning pattern: one heatwave can set the stage for another, more intense heat event in the following weeks by removing moisture from the soil.

articles.title: Climate change may shrink global economy in future: Expert
articles.author: News Room
articles.summary: Climate change could play a role in the shrinking of the global economy in the future. Erhan Aslanoglu from Istanbul Bilgi University said the impact of climate change on industry, tourism, and agriculture affects not only the environment but also economic indicators. A study by the University of New South Wales in Australia found that macroeconomic loss projections worsened depending on the greenhouse gas emissions scenario.

articles.title: The Bell Tolls for the Planet
articles.author: Contributor
articles.summary: Methane is 20 times more potent than CO2. The Arctic University of Norway reports melting glaciers in the Arctic are releasing substantial amounts of methane into the atmosphere. The concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is at its highest point in 800,000 years. Humans burning fossil fuels led to intensified storms and weather-related disasters. The administration cut the staff and funds of the National Climate Assessment and wants to eliminate scientific research at NOAA. The head of the E.P.A. wants to fire 1,155 scientists and slash the EPA's budget.

articles.title: Massive freeze devastates crops across Turkey, sparking food inflation concerns
articles.summary: Severe agricultural freeze has affected 36 provinces across Turkey, causing extensive damage to crops and raising concerns about food inflation and supply chain disruptions. Key agricultural products including fruit trees, vegetables, and vineyards have been damaged. Opposition deputy Ömer Fethi Gürer points to climate change as a driving factor. He proposes to increase state support for agricultural insurance.

articles.title: Mar-Apr 2022 heatwaves in India caused by high altitude wind patterns dry soil conditions IITB
articles.summary: Wind patterns in high altitude and very dry soil conditions caused back-to-back heatwaves in India in 2022, says a study by Indian Institute of Technology Bombay and Johannes Gutenberg-University Mainz, Germany. The March heatwave was mainly linked to a sudden increase in the amplitude of short-lived atmospheric Rossby waves. The April heatwave largely caused by dry soil and advection of heat to India from Pakistan and Afghanistan.

articles.title: Maharashtra News: Hailstorm Damages Crops Across Jalgaon
articles.author: Vijay Pathak
articles.summary: Severe hailstorm damaged banana and maize crops in Raver, Muktainagar, Bodwad and Jalgaon talukas. The unseasonal weather uprooted banana orchards in 19 villages including Raver town. The storm disrupted traffic on Burhanpur-Ankleshwar National Highway due to fallen trees and damaged power lines.

articles.title: Decoding Heatwaves: Wind and Soil Dynamics in India
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Back-to-back heatwaves in India during 2022 were caused by changes in wind patterns and dry soil conditions, according to a study by the Indian Institute of Technology Bombay and Johannes Gutenberg-University Mainz, Germany. Understanding these dynamics is vital for better prediction and mitigation of future heat events.

articles.title: Cyprus Institute urges immediate climate adaptation investment
articles.author: Sigma Live English
articles.summary: The Cyprus Institute has called for urgent investment in climate adaptation. It warns that delays could lead to spiralling state costs from natural disasters. Climate change disproportionately affects vulnerable households in Cyprus, which is expected to experience some of the most severe climate impacts in Europe. The Institute's policy paper highlights the risks of inaction.

articles.title: Communicators' workshop on non-economic climate impacts [India]
articles.summary: Internews' Earth Journalism Network is organizing a three-day Communicators' Workshop on Uncounted Loss and Damage in the Bay of Bengal. The workshop will be held in Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh, India, from June 19 to 21. It will focus on climate impacts that are not easily quantifiable, such as cultural loss, displacement and mental health. Applicants should be communicators based in India from print, online, radio and television outlets.

articles.title: Sea-level rise threatens Vancouver Island communities
articles.author: Kevin Laird
articles.summary: Scientists warn that by 2050, some coastal areas could be permanently underwater. Coastal communities on Vancouver Island are confronting the accelerating impacts of climate change. Indigenous communities are among the most affected by rising seas and are proactive in preparing for them. Some communities have completed sea-level rise mapping and risk assessments, while others have updated their community plans to reflect the new climate reality. Funding gaps remain.

articles.title: Sea-level rise threatens Vancouver Island communities
articles.author: Kevin Laird
articles.summary: By 2050, some coastal areas of Vancouver Island could be permanently underwater due to climate change. First Nations are among the most affected by rising seas and are proactive in preparing for them. Many Indigenous communities face significant barriers, limited funding, jurisdictional overlap, and aging infrastructure.

articles.title: IIT Bombay Study Reveals Why South Asia Faced Recurring Extreme Heatwaves In Early Spring 2022
articles.author: FPJ News Service
articles.summary: South Asian countries experienced back-to-back extreme heat events in early spring of 2022. The March heatwave was mainly linked to a sudden increase in the amplitude of short-lived atmospheric Rossby waves. The April heatwave largely caused by very dry soil conditions and advection of heat to India from Pakistan and Afghanistan.

articles.title: Great Glacier Meltdown Is Coming: What Is It And Why Are Lives of 2 Billion At Stake
articles.author: Ananya Varma
articles.summary: Glaciers are melting at record speeds due to climate change. Norway, Sweden, Svalbard and the tropical Andes are among the worst-affected areas. Eastern Africa has lost 80% of its glaciers in places, and in the Andes, between a third and a half of glaciers have melted since 1998. Glaciers in the Alps and the Pyrenees have shrunk by about 40% over roughly the same period. Global warming is accelerating glacier melt, decreasing snow cover, increasing permafrost thaw, and prompting more extreme rainfall events and natural hazards.

articles.title: Letter to the Editor: Climate Simplified By Bob Moores
articles.author: Spy Desk
articles.summary: Pieter Tans is a climate scientist. For many years he headed NOAA's Carbon Cycle Greenhouse Gases Group. He explains to Bob Moores how greenhouse gases help keep the planet warm. Earth is slowly warming, too slow for some people to realize. Pieter says we are playing Russian Roulette with the heads of our grandchildren.

articles.title: Eco Lunch & Learn On Climate Change
articles.summary: Bermuda College and BEST will hold a free presentation by Dr. Sarah Smith on April 24 titled 'Fisheries & Climate Change: Global Change, Local Consequences' on Thursday, April 25 from 1.00pm to 2.00 pm in room H100, The Athene Lecture Hall.

articles.title: What is a 100-year flood?
articles.author: Nikki Bajema
articles.summary: The term 'once in a lifetime' may not mean what it used to. Warmer air holds more moisture, which means heavier storms and more flooding. Houston had three 500-year floods in three years, including Hurricane Harvey, thanks to climate change.

articles.title: Justine O'Mahony: I'm not cooking. The weather's too fine! Himself is not impressed...
articles.author: Justine O'Mahony
articles.summary: When the sun shines in Ireland, it is such a rare and wonderful occurrence, I immediately down tools. In Australia, employers have to manage heat risks to protect workers health and safety. I'm applying the same rule here, albeit at a lower temperature threshold.

articles.title: Foreign Office warns UK tourists face being ordered to 'evacuate' over 'very sudden' problem
articles.author: Hannah Ahmed
articles.summary: Foreign Office warns Brits heading out of the EU that there is a risk of bushfires in any part of Australia, including areas close to towns and cities. Bushfires can start and change direction and become a risk to life very suddenly. Previous fires resulted in the loss of lives and property and many people were advised to evacuate.

articles.title: Malawi to host LDCs strategy meeting on climate change
articles.author: Chisomo Phiri
articles.summary: Malawi is hosting a strategy meeting of the Least Developed Countries (LDCs) Group from April 15 to 16,2025 at Sunbird Mount Soche Hotel in Blantyre. The LDCs Group comprises 44 nations, spanning Africa, Asia-Pacific and the Caribbean, representing over one billion people.

articles.title: Do I have hay fever? Full list of symptoms and how to get relief
articles.author: Hanna Geissler
articles.summary: There was a surge in pollen levels this weekend. Up to 13 million people are expected to be affected by hay fever. The most common symptoms include sneezing and coughing, a runny or blocked nose, itchy, red or watery eyes, an itchy throat, mouth, nose or ears, loss of smell, headache and tiredness.

articles.title: Scientists issue urgent warning as Arctic data reveals alarming trends: 'Overwhelming amount of change happening'
articles.author: Michael Muir
articles.summary: Arctic sea ice levels are at record lows, and some areas will be ice-free entirely in the summer months. The loss of sea ice is a death knell for Arctic wildlife and the 400,000 Indigenous people who call the Arctic home. Russia has almost half of the Arctic's landmass, but because of the ongoing war in Ukraine, Russia is currently a pariah state in the global community. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which monitors conditions in the Arctic, has been ordered to cut 10% of its workforce. Arctic research is on pause until hostilities cease.

articles.title: Climate Change and Assam
articles.author: Sentinel Digital Desk
articles.summary: Climate change in Assam is affecting agriculture, livelihoods, and infrastructure. Assam has already started experiencing a significant increase in annual mean temperature. Monsoons are becoming erratic and unpredictable, with periods of heavy rainfall followed by prolonged dry spells. The tea industry is facing the most immediate effect, particularly of erratic rainfall and rising temperature. Unicef has warned that climate change will affect children the most.

articles.title: Greens attempt to ‘steal' Australian ‘futures' with radical solar policy
articles.summary: Geologist Ian Plimer says the Greens are trying to 'steal people's futures' amid speculation concerning the party's new radical solar policy. Mr Plimer believes the Greens stand for sexual weirdos, Hamas, mass immigration, and sending the average person broke. The danger is that they'll be in a coalition with Labor.

articles.title: Growing Number Of Maui Residents Worry About Climate Change
articles.author: Caitlin Thompson
articles.summary: Maui residents are more concerned about global warming in 2024 than in 2022. Kaua'i County residents are least concerned about climate change. Most people in Hawaii want action from all levels of government and their communities to combat climate change, including more than 70% of people in Hawai'i.

articles.title: Scientists uncover surprising evidence after studying ancient polar bears: 'Skeletal elements'
articles.author: Mandy Carr
articles.summary: A new study published in Nature shows how a changing climate led polar bears to interact with humans 4,700 to 2,500 years ago. The study looked at remains in Margaret Bay and Amaknak Bridge. It showed that the bears used expanding ice to get to new habitats. They ventured into Unalaska Bay, which was home to the Unangax people. They harvested both polar and brown bears locally during the Neoglacial phase.

articles.title: ‘Creeping socialism': Australia's biggest issues in federal election campaign analysed
articles.summary: Andrew Bolt discusses the promises being made in the federal election campaign and how Australia is facing an issue of 'creeping socialism'. The prime minister went to Tasmania to say he was going to save a paper mill, but he was saving it from his own global warming madness.

articles.title: Lake Erie's icy winter bodes well for fish, birds
articles.author: Peter Krouse
articles.summary: Lake Erie's ice coverage was above average for most of February and some of January and March. It peaked at 95% on Feb. 20. It was down to about 1% last week, according to the federal Great Lakes Environmental Research Laboratory. It usually means good things for creatures that depend on Lake Erie.

articles.title: Rising temperatures could cause a surge in mental health disorders with young Australians most at risk
articles.summary: Rising temperatures could lead to a surge in mental disorders among young Australians in coming years. The Northern Territory has the highest predicted risk and the highest average temperature. South Australia and Victoria had the highest proportion of mental health burden attributable to high temperature. This summer, thousands died during extreme heat events in the northern hemisphere.

articles.title: Nigeria FG to Roll Out Flood Awareness Campaign Nationwide Starting May 2025
articles.author: Nigeria News
articles.summary: The Nigerian government will launch a flood awareness campaign in May 2025. The campaign will target 1,249 communities in 30 states and the FCT, identified as at high risk of flooding due to changing weather patterns. In 2024, floods displaced over 740,000 people and killed 321 people in Nigeria.

articles.title: International Migration 14 April
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Annual migrant arrivals peaked at 234,800 in the year ended October 2023. Annual migrant departures peaked at 122,000 in January 2025. Annual net migration peaked in the same year with a gain of 135,500. Annual migration statistics are based on outcomes-based measure of migration.

articles.title: Workshops Ready Residents for Bushfire Season
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Cardinia Shire Council is hosting practical workshops to support residents with bushfire preparedness. Workshops are aimed at properties with a bushfire risk between 1 and 10 hectares. Participants will develop a greater understanding of: Safety and Legal requirements when undertaking a planned burn, common planned burning and firefighting equipment, and how to prepare control lines using a rakehoe.

articles.title: Can the giants handle the heat?
articles.author: Naomi Parris
articles.summary: There was an increase in temperatures over the past two years in Guyana's Rupununi region. Between January and May, 91,128 fires were reported and 5045.45 square miles of land was burned in the region. The region is dry, hot and has lots of dry vegetation, which can be seen as fuel. Wildlife like giant anteaters, tapirs, jaguars and kingfishers are struggling to adapt to a changing environment.

articles.title: Farmers worried as rain damages wheat crop
articles.summary: Banke was hit by heavy rain and heavy winds on Sunday evening. The unseasonal rain damaged the wheat crop in Banke. The wheat crop that had just been harvested and those in the field was also damaged. The lentils were also damaged by the rain.

articles.title: Summit hope for state if election climate favours Labor
articles.summary: Adelaide would host a major global climate conference in 2026 if Australia's bid is successful and Peter Dutton loses the federal election. The host of COP31 will be announced at this year's event in November. Mr Dutton in late March called the bid "madness" and argued it would cost tens of billions of dollars.

articles.title: Summit hope for state if election climate favours Labor
articles.author: Jacob Shteyman
articles.summary: Adelaide will host a major global climate conference in 2026 if Australia's bid is successful and Peter Dutton loses the federal election. The host of COP31 will be announced at this year's event in November. The conference would help repair relationships with Pacific Island nations dismayed by the former coalition government's stance on climate change and boost the local economy.

articles.title: Summit hope for state if election climate favours Labor
articles.author: Jacob Shteyman
articles.summary: Adelaide would host a major global climate conference in 2026 if Australia's bid is successful and Peter Dutton loses the federal election. If Australia is successful, the conference would take place in Adelaide, as long as Dutton does not win the election.

articles.title: Summit hope for state if election climate favours Labor
articles.author: Jacob Shteyman
articles.summary: Adelaide would host a major global climate conference in 2026 if Australia's bid is successful and Peter Dutton loses the federal election. If Australia is successful, the conference would take place in Adelaide, as long as Dutton does not win the election.

articles.title: Climate Emergency Camden: Council failing over climate change
articles.author: Camden Council
articles.summary: Camden Council changed its constitution to take due care to protect us against the harmful impacts of climate change. The constitution requires all scrutiny committees to consider the greenhouse gas (CO2e) emissions that would result from the council's decisions. The culture and environment scrutiny committee rarely finds the time to discuss these matters. Camden approved the demolition and rebuilding of the Euston Tower, whose construction will cause 46,000 tonnes of CO2e emissions. The Bacton Estate redevelopment in Gospel Oak will produce at least 50,000 tons of carbon emissions.

articles.title: Andean Women Farmers in Peru Face Climate Crisis with Green Practices
